The Air Situation.
(Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 29th Conclusions, Minute 1.)
Dropping of leaflets in Germany. (Previous Reference: W.M. (39) 28th Conclusions, Minute 2.)
1. The Secretary of State for Air informed the War Cabinet that the reconnaissance carried out the previous day over the west and north-west of Germany had been very successful, and that photographs had been obtained of 17 out of 18 aerodromes. All aircraft returned without having encountered enemy fighters, though strong anti-aircraft fire was experienced over the Ruhr. The results of this reconnaissance had yet to be examined in more detail, but first impressions suggested there was little or no camouflage, and that air activity was slight. There were some indications from other sources that aircraft, formerly concentrated in north-west Germany, had returned to their parent aerodromes for maintenance.
A reconnaissance was carried out the previous night of roads and railways behind the Low Countries, and another was being made that morning.
Leaflets were dropped during the previous day's reconnaissances, all aircraft returning safely.
Attention was drawn to the fact that reports had appeared in this morning's Press regarding the dropping of leaflets, notwithstanding the Cabinet decision noted in the margin. It was explained that this had occurred through some error, and that steps would be taken to prevent a recurrence of this mistake.
The War Cabinet took note of this statement.
The Naval Situation.
(Previous Reference!: ''J W.M. (39) 29th Conclusions, Minute 2.)
H.M.S. Spearfish.
Attack by German Flying boats on the Fleet.
2. The First Lord of the Admiralty said that, if nothing untoward happened before 1 p.m. that day, four days would have passed without any British merchant ship having been sunk or molested. By contrast, we were continuing vigorously to press home our attacks on enemy submarines, which included during the past twenty-four hours a number of attacks in which good contact had been obtained.
Meanwhile, the convoy system was working well. Our ships were met far out to sea by our destroyers, who then escorted them in.
The First Lord gave an account of the experiences of the Spearfish, the submarine which had been damaged off Heligoland. The submarine had now returned, and it was hoped to obtain valuable information from the officers and crew, which would throw light on German methods of submarine detection.
The Spearfish had been met at 1 o'clock the previous day by four destroyers and then escorted home by the Fleet. At about 11 a.m. three German flying-boats appeared in the vicinity of the Fleet, flying at roughly 200 feet above sea level. (It was the crew of one of these flying-boats which had been captured.) Later, our ships had been attacked in force by bombers. Dive bombing attacks had been carried out on the Hood and the Ark Royal from clouds, out of a blue sky, from 6,000 feet. There had been no direct hit, but one ship had sustained a graze which had done little damage. These attacks had been succeeded by a high altitude bombing attack on the Aurora and Sheffield at 5 15 p.m. In this case, twenty-six bombs had been dropped, and all had missed.
Our anti-aircraft fire had been ineffective. The First Lord accounted for this by the fact that our practice in the past had been confined to sleeve targets towed at about 100 m.p.h. It was essential that arrangements should immediately be made to begin practices against high-speed targets of the order of 250 m.p.h.
It was agreed that the necessary arrangements to this end should be set in train between the Admiralty and Air Ministry.
At 11 a.m. the previous morning two German aircraft arrived off May Island in Scotland and attacked two of our escort vessels,

Our warning system seemed to have been at fault (possibly the result of previous false alarms). It was agreed that steps should be taken by the Air Ministry to ensure better warning of the approach of hostile aircraft.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.
The Military Situation.
(Previous Ref erence: W.M. (39) 29th Conclusions, Minute 3.)
3. The Secretary of State for War informed the War Cabinet that the Germans claimed to have captured Warsaw, but that Modlin and the Hela Peninsula were still holding out.
On the Western Front, one more Landwehr division had been identified, but there was no corroboration yet of the widespread reports from neutral countries that a large German concentration was taking place. It was possible that these reports were spread by the Germans themselves.
The Secretary of State for War described the steps being taken to produce a strongly fortified line for the occupation of the British Expeditionary Force.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

In fact the War Cabinet had not done more than agree that the Ambassador should sound> General Chiang Kai-shek as to his attitude towards the Japanese suggestion forwarded by Sir Robert Craigie. The Chiefs of Staff had expressed the opinion that from the strictly military point of view the prolongation of the Sino-Japanese conflict was to the advantage of this country.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs said that he thought that the position had now been made perfectly clear to His Majesty's Ambassador, Shanghai, in a further telegram (No. 963) which he had sent him the previous afternoon (the 27th September, 1939). On the general question of our attitude towards the Sino-Japanese conflict, it should be remembered that the Chiefs of Staff had qualified their advice by stressing the importance of doing nothing which might exasperate the Japanese Government into taking action against us.
The Chief of the Air Staff said that the Chiefs of Staff Committee had now prepared a report recording the conclusions which he had communicated to the War Cabinet at their meeting held on the 26th September, 1939.
The Prime Minister said that in his view it was to our interest to steer a middle course and to avoid giving offence either to the Chinese or the Japanese Governments. It was important to encourage those elements in Japan which were friendly to us. At the same time we must be careful not to prejudice General Chiang Kai-shek's position in any way.
The War Cabinet-Took note of the discussion and asked to be furnished with the appreciation prepared by the Chiefs of Staff Committee on the situation reached in the Sino-Japanese hostilities.

13. The Prime Minister drew the attention of his colleagues to the weekly, fortnightly and monthly Reports which they were now receiving, as a result of the decision taken at the meeting referred to in the margin. With the exception of the Reports circulated by the Service Ministers and by the Chiefs of Staff, these documents had not so far been placed on the Agenda paper for any meeting of the War Cabinet. He suggested that there should be special meetings of the War Cabinet, perhaps twice a month, at which the business would be the consideration of these periodical Reports.
The War Cabinet agreed :
(i) that special meetings should be held to consider the
periodical Reports submitted by Departments, the first such meeting to be held on a day to be arranged in the following week;
(ii) to invite Departments to append to these Reports, in
suitable cases, a summary of Conclusions or recommendations. (This would not, of course, apply to those Reports which are in effect summaries of information under a few main headings.)

The Secretary of State for War had Conclusions, indicated that, while he was prepared to work the scheme, he Minute 15.) thought it would be better that each Department should be responsible for the issue of information to the press on matters which concerned it. This was very much the conclusion which had been forming in his own mind. He had discussed the matter the previous day with Lord Macmillan, who had formed the same view. He was satisfied that it would be better from every point of view that each Department should be responsible for the issue of material to the Press on its own subjects.
